facilitating, new kinds of interpersonal
encounters inside and outside the museum,

3226.text:
critical artists and heterotopic
institutions have

3230.text:
been able to disrupt the fabric of
social life in order to encourage

3233.text:
thought about and action toward social
change.

3237.text: "Untitled Free/Still" of 1995 is one of Rirkrit Tiravanija's earliest

3242.text:
experiments in this vein. Working with
museum staff, we organized this project at

3249.text:
the Contemporary Art Center in
Cincinnati,

3252.text:
Tiravanija supplanted routine gallery activities
with the continuous activity of

3256.text:
preparing and serving a free Thai curry
to visitors.

3261.text:
The exhibition space was transformed
into a makeshift kitchen with the

3264.text:
introduction of a few small appliances
and cookware. All other elements of his

3268.text:
cafe were pulled directly from museum
offices and storerooms. As meals are

3272.text:
prepared, served, and consumed through the
run of the show,

3276.text:
waste from the process, including empty
bottles and cans, used utensils, and

3280.text:
leftovers, accumulate and become part of
the installation. "Untitled Free/Still"

3285.text:
strategically replaces a culture of
looking with a participatory ritual. The

3291.text:
audience becomes an active part of the
installation performance, for without

3295.text:
viewers to consume the food prepared by
museum staff, the work is in complete.

3299.text:
Tiravanija's professional kitchen is
merely a device to encourage the

3305.text:
communication and the service that is
the actual subject of the work, and the

3310.text:
most often unfulfilled promise of
cultural institutions. The museum context

3315.text:
offers a frame in which the larger
implications of this activity,

3319.text:
particularly for art practices that lack
direct social relevance, can properly be

3324.text:
understood. And the last
and probably the most fun because it actually

3332.text:
sublime social encounters: the sense of
mingled awe, fear, and wonder, inspired by

3339.text:
encounters with transcendent,
immeasurably vast phenomena identified

3343.text:
as sublime, and privileged in certain
aesthetics, has, as we discussed at the

3348.text:
outset of this talk, most often been
conceived as the outcome of an encounter

3353.text:
between one viewer and one image or
object. While this encounter may well be

3358.text:
recalled and discussed with others after
the fact, it has traditionally been

3361.text:
conceived as a matter of private
experience. By wrenching the phenomena

3367.text:
at the heart of the sublime out of the
picture plane and into shared public

3371.text:
space, on occasion, these phenomena have
been made central to interpersonal

3377.text:
encounters, and thus the locus of
potentially transformative dialogue and

3381.text: collective action. Inigo Manglano-Ovalle's monumental "Cloud Prototype" of 2003

3387.text:
confronts its audience with the specter
of that awesome and terrifying human

3392.text:
creation: the atomic bomb. This enormous
titanium-clad piece, based on a composite

3398.text:
computer image generated from data on
real cumulonimbus clouds, hangs ominously

3404.text:
over the viewers head. From different
angles the form reads as both a swirling

3410.text:
thundercloud and a mushroom cloud. Here
Manglano-Ovalle

3414.text:
updates the visual vocabulary of the
Romantic sublime, conflating a dramatic

3419.text:
staple of 18th century landscape
painting--these dramatic clouds--with the

3424.text:
haunting, iconic image of the aftermath
of a nuclear detonation. Designed and

3430.text:
scaled deliberately for outdoor public
space, "Cloud Prototype" inspires the full

3435.text:
range of responses associated with the
sublime, but remakes the public monument

3440.text:
in a provocative and potentially
incendiary fashion. And the final lesson,

3449.text:
and I learned this only relatively
recently, falling as I do on the wrong

3452.text:
side of the digital divide, the most
effective art institutions now are those

3459.text:
that launch virtual cognates to all of
the aforementioned artistic educational

3466.text:
and social services activities online,
and offer them free of charge.

3471.text:
I'm convinced that all cultural
institutions must in future become

3475.text:
non-profit media companies if they are
to survive and thrive. We can reach, we

3482.text:
know this, many multiples of the audience
we welcome to the physical museum in

3487.text:
cyberspace. I have, as you can see,
learned many lessons and I hope to learn

3494.text:
many more on this journey, but taken
together, these six the clearest

3499.text: alternative, I've discovered, to the antisocial experience programmed into the

3504.text:
white cube. Let me close with a final
reference to Felix Gonzalez-Torres, who you

3511.text:
can probably tell is my Loadstar. In
"Untitled," he offers a powerful formula

3517.text:
for an indispensable kind of art and art
institution. These make individuals and

3524.text:
subpopulations visible regardless of
their real or imagined marginality. They

3530.text:
bring them together to represent
themselves to one another and the world

3533.text:
beyond the museum in ways that encourage
communicative and material exchanges

3538.text:
about and across differences. These
communicative exchanges involve

3545.text:
investigation,critique, and cooperative
rethinking of the deep and deeply flawed

3550.text:
systems of thought and belief that
structure all human interactions, and

3555.text:
these material exchanges aim to correct
social ills that such flawed systems

3560.text:
promote. It is and always will be an
ongoing process because the specific

3567.text:
goals of this art and these institutions,
which I've described as heterotopic,

3571.text:
associated with the eradication of
prejudice, the alleviation of suffering,

3575.text:
and the elevation of the human spirit,
are necessarily shifting,

3580.text:
changing all the time. The larger goal of
this heterotopic art and these

3586.text:
heterotopic art institutions is, however,
unchanging: to make this place, any place,

3593.text: the best place ever. Thank you very much.
